statement.p:
Here is the lunch menu for Damico and Sons.
How many ways can you order a single item for lunch?
There are 2 soups, 7 salad options, 5 signature salad options, and 6 sandwich options. Therefore, there are a total of
2 + 7 + 5 + 6 = 20
possible lunches.
Looking closely, we see that it is possible to "upgrade" our sandwich to come with a Side Caeser or Mixed Green Salad. Taking that into account, there are 18 sandwich options (instead of 6), so there are a total of 32 lunches.
The menu says that you can "choose two to create your favorite combination." How many ways can this be done, according to the rules that they describe?
There are three distinct kinds of combo lunches: soup and salad, soup and sandwich, salad and sandwich. Note that you cannot get a Salad Sampler as part of this deal, so there are a total of 11 salad options. Also, a sandwich update is no longer possible. Therefore, there are a total of
2 \times 11 + 2 \times 6 + 11 \times 6 = 22 + 12 + 66 = 100.
possible lunches.

li.p:
How many possible license plates are there?
10^3 \cdot 26^3

Decorum dictates that some three-letter combinations be outlawed. For each outlawed three-letter combination, how many possible license plates are removed from circulation?
10^3

statement.p:
How many arithmetic problems of the following form are possible. You must use each of the digits 1 through 9, in numerical order from left to right. You can use any combination of + and \times symbols, as long as the expression makes sense. For example, 1234+56789 and 12 \times 3 + 4 \times 5678 \times 9 and 123456789 are valid, but 123 \times \times 4567 + 89 is not.
There are eight spaces between the digits. For each space we have three choices: nothing, + or \times. Therefore, the total number of arithmetic problems is 3^8.

li.p:
How many numbers from 1000 to 9999 are odd?
\underbrace{5}_{\mbox{choose 4th digit}} \times \underbrace{9}_{\mbox{choose 1st digit}} \times \underbrace{10}_{\mbox{choose 2nd digit}} \times \underbrace{10}_{\mbox{choose 3rd digit}}

How many numbers from 0 to 1000 contain exactly one 3?
We consider all possible 3 digit numbers, where we can have a 0 in the first digit (so we write 003 instead of 3). There are three cases, depending on the location of the 3. In each case, we have 9 choices for each of the other two digits, so the answer is
(9 \times 9) + (9 \times 9) + (9 \times 9) = 243

In how many ways can k men and k women be seated around a circular table? Before anyone sits down, all chairs are identical.
\frac{(2k)!}{2k} = (2k-1)!
We place people into seats, starting at the top of the table and continuing clockwise. There are (2k)! ways to do this. However, by the symmetry of the table, we can shift everyone over by one seat (or two seats, or three seats...) and get the same configuration. Therefore we must divide by 2k, which is the number of possible rotations.

In how many ways can this be done if the men and women must sit in alternate seats?
\frac{k! k!}{k} = k! (k-1)!
Here is one proof of this result.
Start off with a line containing 2k spots.
Case 1: people line up MFMF...MF. Number of ways: k! k!
Case 2: people line up FMFM...FM. Number of ways: k! k!
Total number of ways to line up: 2 ( k! k!)
Turn the line into a circle. Each circular arrangement is created 2k times.
Final answer is \frac{2 (k! k!)}{2k} = \frac{k! k! }{ k} = k! (k-1)!
Here is another way to argue this that is quicker, but more subtle:
Pick any chair (it doesn't matter). Starting at that chair, place all the men in every other chair, going clockwise. Number of ways: k!
Now place the women going clockwise, starting at the empty chair to the right of the first man. Number of ways: k!
Accounting for the circular symmetry, each configuration is created k times.
Final answer is \frac{k! k!}{ k} = k! (k-1)!.

In how many ways can this be done if there are two women (and maybe more) sitting next to one another?
We just subtract our answer in part (b) from our answer in part (a) to get
(2k-1)! - k! (k-1)!

statement.p:
Four sisters and their spouses have been invited to a reception where these 8 people will be seating in a row of 8 chairs. Each married couple must be seated together.
How many ways can this be done?
4! \times 2^4
There are 4! ways to arrange the couples, and then 2 ways to seat each couple next to one another
How many ways can this be done if no sister sits next to any other sister?
4! \times 5
There are 4! ways to arrange the couples. Let us start seating the couples from left to right, in chairs labeled by [8]. As soon as one sister sits in an even chair, this forces the remaining sisters to sit in an even chair. There is 1 way for the sisters to all sit in odd chairs. Otherwise, there are 4 ways to choose the first even chair taken by a sister. So there are a total of 4! \times 5 possible arrangements.
How many ways can this be done if every sister must sit next to one of her sisters?
We give two solutions.
4! = 24
Again, there are 4! ways to arrange the couples. There is one way to seat the first couple, since the sister cannot be on the end. This also forces the arrangement of the second couple. Likewise, the 3rd and 4th couples only have one possible arrangement.
Here is another way to argue it. The configuration must be of the form PSSPPSSP where P= partner and S= sister. Our answer is
{4 \choose 2} \cdot 2 \cdot 2.
First, we choose the two sisters that will appear in spots 2 and 3. There are two ways to arrange them. The remaining two sisters must sit in spots 6 and 7. Again, there are two ways to arrange them. The placement of the partners is then forced by the seat of their spouses.
How many ways can this be done if at least one pair of sisters sits next to one another?
4! (2^4 - 5)
We subtract part (b) from part (a) to get the answer.

li.p:
Find a closed formula for the sum \displaystyle{\sum_{k=0}^n {n \choose k} 2^k}.
By the binomial theorem,
3^n = (2 + 1)^n = \sum_{k=0}^n {n \choose k} 2^k.

Devise a situation that is counted by this sum. Then give a "combinatorial proof" by explaining why both the closed formula and the one given above count all configurations.
Here is one story that works. Suppose there are n kids who want ice cream. There are three flavors to choose from: vanilla, chocolate and strawberry. How many possible outcomes are there?
Each kid has 3 choices, so there are 3^n possible outcomes.
We can count this outcome in two phases. First, determine the number k of kids ordering vanilla or chocolate. (The remaining n-k get strawberry.) Next, determine which of these k kids wants vanilla and which one wants chocolate. For each k, we can choose the choco-vanilla kids in {n \choose k} ways, and then determine their status in 2^k ways. We must sum over 0 \leq k \leq n to get all possible outcomes.

How many ways are there to place 8 rooks on an 8 \times 8 chessboard so that no two may attack one another?
There can only be one rook in each row and one rook in each column. Each valid configuration corresponds to a bijection between the rows and columns. There are 8! possibilities.

How many ways are there to place 5 black rooks and 3 white rooks on an 8 \times 8 chessboard so that no two may attack one another?
Place the rooks in 2 phases. Phase 1: place 8 "gray" rooks. Phase 2: decide which of the 8 rooks are black. The entire process can occur in 8! \times {8 \choose 5} ways.

How many ways are there to place 5 rooks on an 8 \times 8 chessboard so that no two may attack one another?
Phase 1: Choose 5 rows (in {8 \choose 5} ways)
Phase 2: Choose 5 columns (in {8 \choose 5} ways)
Phase 3: List the chosen rows in increasing orders. Assign each of the columns to one of these rows (in 5! ways)
Place your 5 rooks in the resulting (row,column) pairs. So the number of configurations is
{8 \choose 5} \times {8 \choose 5} \times 5!

How many diagonals are there?
\frac{n (n-3)}{2}
Choose the first vertex in n different ways
Choose the second vertex in n-3 different ways (we can't pick the first vertex again and we can't pick either of its neighbors).
We've picked each diagonal twice.

How many intersections do the diagonals determine?
{n \choose 4}
If we choose 4 vertices, there is exactly one way to pair them up to get crossing diagonals. If our vertices in clockwise order are v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4 then we must pair v_1 with v_3 and v_2 with v_4.
So there is a bijection between intersections of diagonals and 4-sets of vertices.
